body:
Thank you for your pull request. Before we can look at your contribution, we need to ensure all contributors are covered by a Contributor License Agreement.

After the following items are addressed, please respond with a new comment here, and the automated system will re-verify.

* User @dgquintas isn't covered by a CLA. They will need to complete the form at https://identity.linuxfoundation.org/projects/cncf

_Regards,
The Linux Foundation CLA GitHub bot_
There's a p0 bug to reenable this right?
@ctiller There's a P1 one: https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/13128 It could be P0 if someone had the cycles to tackle it right away (I don't). I still plan on treating it as P1 myself.

There's a higher rate of tests getting disabled and disappearing into the
void than I'd like right now.

On Thu, Oct 26, 2017 at 11:25 AM David G. Quintas <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> @ctiller <https://github.com/ctiller> There's a P1 one: #13128
> <https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/13128> It could be P0 if someone had
> the cycles to tackle it right away (I don't). I still plan on treating it
> as P1 myself.
>
> 窶能n> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
>
>
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/13159#issuecomment-339755498>, or mute
> the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AJpudSSui1uv_QXtXDjTSwD3O4_babikks5swM6HgaJpZM4QH8Rt>
> .
>

Alternative concern: list the tests that have been reenabled because
they're fixed in the past year.

On Thu, Oct 26, 2017, 11:30 AM Craig Tiller <ctiller@google.com> wrote:

> There's a higher rate of tests getting disabled and disappearing into the
> void than I'd like right now.
>
> On Thu, Oct 26, 2017 at 11:25 AM David G. Quintas <
> notifications@github.com> wrote:
>
>> @ctiller <https://github.com/ctiller> There's a P1 one: #13128
>> <https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/13128> It could be P0 if someone
>> had the cycles to tackle it right away (I don't). I still plan on treating
>> it as P1 myself.
>>
>> 窶能n>> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
>>
>>
>> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
>> <https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/13159#issuecomment-339755498>, or mute
>> the thread
>> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AJpudSSui1uv_QXtXDjTSwD3O4_babikks5swM6HgaJpZM4QH8Rt>
>> .
>>
>

I understand, but this disables only epollex for the LB family of tests. The alternative is to have them continue to introduce noise in the already very bad failing tests situation. Of course the way to address that is fixing whatever is causing the issue. After discussing the priority of epollex vs addressing flakiness, it was agreed that the latter was more pressing. 

It's very much on my radar to look more into what's causing this (beyond what's described in #13128).

My plan still stands to enable epollex globally in the next couple of weeks.

On Thu, Oct 26, 2017, 11:39 AM David G. Quintas <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> I understand, but this disables only epollex for the LB family of tests.
> The alternative is to have them continue to introduce noise in the already

> pressing.
>
> It's very much on my radar to look more into what's causing this (beyond
> what's described in #13128 <https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/13128>).
>

>
>
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/13159#issuecomment-339760002>, or mute
> the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AJpudc--3hlWw3qFcvdVKdbLgS_oi72sks5swNHegaJpZM4QH8Rt>
> .
>

It would inspire more confidence if reenabling tests was a thing we ever
did.

> My plan still stands to enable epollex globally in the next couple of
